title: Ladybrook Valley Interest Trail Walking Route

images.title: Gary Barber / MiddleWood Way as Seen from the Ladybrook Valley Interest Trail
images.caption: The Middlewood Way as seen from the trail. This shared cycling and walking trail links with the trail running in one direction to Macclesfield and Marple in the other.

images.title: Mike Harris / Micker Brook (Lady Brook)
images.caption: Micker Brook (Lady Brook) - on the Ladybrook Valley Trail, Cheadle. Beginning in the English Peak District, the Ladybrook Valley passes through Stockport, Disley, Hazel Grove and Cheadle. The brook drops 275 metres over the course of its 9 miles. It goes by the names Bollinhurst Brook, Norbury Brook, Bramhall Brook, Ladybrook, and Mickerbrook at various points. The Ladybrook is a tributary of the River Mersey, the confluence being near to Cheadle Village, immediately after flowing under the M60 motorway.

images.title: Mike Harris / Park beside Micker Brook
images.caption: Park beside Micker Brook, from the Ladybrook Valley Trail looking towards the A5149 (Wilmslow Road).

images.title: Tricia Neal / Bramall Hall, Stockport
images.caption: Bramall Hall. The Tudor Manor House has origins dating back to the Middle Ages. You can visit the hall and find out all about its fascinating history and magnificent 16th Century wall paintings. There's also some nice walks in the 70 acres of parkland and woodland surrounding the building.

images.title: Ladybrook Valley Interest Trail, Lady Brook by John Topping, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Nice section along the brook

description: This walk follows various brooks from Cheadle to Disley via Hazel Grove . You start off at Abney Hall Park in Cheadle. The park has lovely grounds and the interesting Abney Hall built in 1847 and makes for a fine start point. From here you follow the Micker Brook to the grand Brammall Hall . Bramall Hall is one of Cheshire's grandest black and white timber-framed Tudor manor houses and also has 70 acres of beautiful parkland. The trail then joins the Lady Brook, following it to Poynton Park in Hazel Grove where you will walk alongside the attractive Poynton Lake. The final section takes you along Norbury Brook to Middlewood, before crossing the Macclesfield Canal and finishing at Disley.
